Authors:
Zuraifah Asrah Mohamad, Lena Ciric, Christopher Charles
Kibbler
Title:
Characterisation of Stachybotrys spp. using PCR and
Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization-Time of Flight (MALDI-TOF)
Mass Spectrometry Characterisation of Stachybotrys spp. using PCR and
Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization-Time of Flight (MALDI-TOF)
Mass Spectrometry
Keywords:
Identification, mass spectral profiles (MSPs),
Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization-Time of Flight (MALDI-TOF),
polymerase chain reaction (PCR), Stachybotrys spp., trichodiene synthase
(tri5), universal primer.
Abstract:
There have been continuous revisions in the identification
of Stachybotrys spp. due to developments in laboratory techniques since
the genus was proposed by Corda in 1837. One of the species, S.
chartarum, is also known as a species complex fungus where
discrimination between closely related species can prove challenging.
The aim of this study was to identify members of the S. chartarum
species complex and distinguish them from morphologically similar
Stachybotrys spp. with confidence using PCR and MALDI-TOF-based
characterisation methods. Stachybotrys spp. strains (n = 13)
representing five different species were obtained from various sources
for this study. A universal PCR primer set (ITS1/4) suitable for
identification at genus level, misidentified some of the strains at
species level. However, the trichodiene synthase (tri5) gene, which is
involved in the trichothecenes biosynthetic pathway, provided a reliable
and more specific method for identifying S. chartarum and S.
chlorohalonata, although nucleotide and phylogenetic patterns differed
between the pre-existing and novel tri5 primer sets used. Moreover, one
of the novel primer sets, SC3, was specific to S. chartarum. The
standard Bruker method for protein extraction for Matrix-Assisted Laser
Desorption Ionization-Time of Flight (MALDI-TOF) Mass Spectrometry was
successfully employed without additional reagent steps or melanin
suppression. Using in-house generated mass spectrum profiles (MSPs) of
Stachybotrys chartarum, NCPF 7597, all S. chartarum isolates grown in
Sabouraud dextrose broth were identified with high probability to the
species level, S. chlorohalonata as probable Stachybotrys species, and
other Stachybotrys species could not be reliably identified. In this
study, we have developed and demonstrated the value of two rapid novel
approaches to the identification of Stachybotrys chartarum sensu
stricto, suitable for use in the routine mycology laboratory.
